fieldAliases.description: Represents a time, encoded as a 64 bit unsigned integer representing the number of nanoseconds since the Unix epoch.
fieldAliases.name: Timestamp

fieldAliases.description: A representation of a bitcoin address in raw format, with no check sum or encoding.
fieldAliases.name: Address

fieldAliases.description: Represents a Bitcoin transaction ID, the double SHA256 hash of the serialized transaction.
fieldAliases.name: TxId

fieldAliases.description: The type/format of the sender's proof of identity. 0 - not included, 1 - PaymailProof, 2 - IdentityOracleProof
fieldAliases.name: ProofOfIdentityType

fieldAliases.description: A type of entity. (i.e. Individual, Public Company)
fieldAliases.name: EntityType

fieldAliases.description: A role within an entity. (i.e. CEO, CFO)
fieldAliases.name: Role

fieldAliases.description: Represents a unique identifier for an instrument/token.
fieldAliases.name: InstrumentCode

fieldTypes.description: Administrator is used to refer to a Administration role in an Entity.

fields.description: Chairman, Director, Managing Partner, etc.. Found in 'Roles' in Specification/Resources
fields.label: Administrator Type
fields.name: Type

fields.description: Length 0-255 bytes. 0 is valid.
fields.label: Administrator Name
fields.name: Name

fieldTypes.label: Administrator
fieldTypes.name: Administrator

fieldTypes.description: Information about an entity in a channel.

fields.description: The address representing the locking script that is required to perform entity administrative level operations on a channel. Such as add/remove a member, accept/reject proposals, and requesting/receiving payments. This is recommended to be an m of n multi-signature address.
fields.label: Administrative Address
fields.name: AdministrativeAddress

fields.description: Specifies the output containing the locking script for the party. It should also be included in the M1 ReceiverIndexes. That output must respond with a proof of identity that identifies the company involved.
fields.label: Output Index
fields.name: OutputIndex

fieldTypes.label: Channel Party
fieldTypes.name: ChannelParty

fields.description: Full name, including file extension, of the file. Length 0-255 bytes. 0 is valid.
fields.label: Document Name
fields.name: Name

fields.description: MIME type of the file. Length 0-255 bytes. 0 is valid.
fields.label: MIME Type
fields.name: Type

fields.description: The contents of the file.
fields.label: File Contents
fields.name: Contents

fieldTypes.description: Entity represents the details of a legal Entity, such as a public or private company, government agency, or and individual.

fields.description: Length 1-255 bytes (0 is not valid). Issuing entity (company, organization, individual).  Can be any unique identifying string, including human readable names for branding/vanity purposes.
fields.label: Name
fields.name: Name

fields.description: The type of entity. (i.e Public Company, Individual) (Specification/Resources).
fields.label: Type
fields.name: Type

fields.description: Null is valid. A Legal Entity Identifier (or LEI) is an international identifier made up of a 20-character identifier that identifies distinct legal entities that engage in financial transactions. It is defined by ISO 17442.[1] Natural persons are not required to have an LEI; theyâ€™re eligible to have one issued, however, but only if they act in an independent business capacity.[2] The LEI is a global standard, designed to be non-proprietary data that is freely accessible to all.[3] As of December 2018, over 1,300,000 legal entities from more than 200 countries have now been issued with LEIs.
fields.label: Legal Entity Identifier
fields.name: LEI

fields.description: Issuer/Entity/Contracting Party X Address Details (eg. HQ)
fields.label: Unit Number
fields.name: UnitNumber

fields.description: Length 0-255 bytes. Address for text-based communication: eg. email address, Bitcoin address
fields.label: Email Address
fields.name: EmailAddress

fields.description: Length 0-255 bytes. 0 is valid. Phone Number for Entity.
fields.label: Phone Number
fields.name: PhoneNumber

fields.description: A list of people that are in Administrative Roles for the Entity.  eg. Chair, Director, Managing Partner, etc.
fields.label: Administration
fields.name: Administration

fields.description: A list of people in Management Roles for the Entity. e.g CEO, COO, CTO, CFO, Secretary, Executive, etc.
fields.label: Management
fields.name: Management

fields.description: Domain name owned by this entity. Length 0-255 bytes. 0 is valid.
fields.label: Domain Name
fields.name: DomainName

fields.description: Deprecated for separate field in contract. Address of entity contract. When the contract type is instrument contract, or a child type, this field refers to the entity specified in the contract at the address specified. When this field is present, no other fields should be included in the entity.
fields.label: Entity Contract Address
fields.name: EntityContractAddress

fields.description: Length 0-255 bytes. Handle containing an alias and domain name performing queries defined in the Paymail protocol.
fields.label: Paymail Handle
fields.name: PaymailHandle

fieldTypes.name: Entity

fields.description: The user id (UUID) in the identity oracle system. Used to request the entity data.
fields.label: User ID
fields.name: UserID

fields.description: PII is not allowed in entity by GDPR, so only company information can be placed in this entity. In the future this might be supported for PII with better understanding of GDPR. The identity being provided. EntityContractAddress is located within this structure.
fields.label: Entity
fields.name: Entity

fields.description: Signature of the serialized entity, public key, and block hash with the identity oracle's public key.

fields.description: Length 0-255 bytes. 0 is valid.

fields.description: The height of the block hash included in the data signed by the oracle. If the value is not included (zero), then no signature hash is included in the signed data.

fields.description: The time frame that the proof is valid.

fields.description: The algorithm used by the oracle signature.

fields.description: Signature of the related data with the oracle's public key.
fields.label: Signature
fields.name: Signature

fieldTypes.description: Reference to a bitcoin transaction output.

fields.description: The index of the output within the referenced transaction.

fields.description: The user id (UUID) in the identity oracle system. Used to request the entity data.

fields.description: PII including personally identifiable user names not allowed by GDPR. This is put in for possible future use without a protocol change. Paymail handle in the form {alias}@{domain}.{tld}

fields.description: The subject / topic of the message.

messages.description: A message that contains a bitcoin transaction that was accepted by the network or an agent and then invalidated by a reorg, or zero conf double spend. This serves as on chain evidence of the sending party's signatures and approval for the given transaction.

fields.description: Timestamp in nanoseconds for when the message sender creates the transaction.
fields.label: Timestamp
fields.name: Timestamp

fields.description: Serialized bitcoin transaction that was reverted/invalidated after being accepted.
fields.label: Transaction
fields.name: Transaction

messages.label: Reverted Tx
messages.name: RevertedTx

messages.description: A message that contains all of the details required for an agreement to be formed. Sent to an address(es). The Offer should have all, or nearly all, of the details required for the receiving party to accept the offer.  The Offer shall be in the form of a partially formed Bitcoin transaction with all of the relevent details (offer, consideration, offeror's payment/receipt details, etc.).  The Offer message is different to a Signature Request message in that it is missing the offeree's payment/receipt details (eg. UTXOs). If the Offer message is well received by the offeree, then the offeree can add their relevent details (eg. inputs/outputs) and sign the transaction.  If an additional signature is required from the offeror at this point, then the partially-signed transaction can be sent to the offeror by way of a Signature Request message.

fields.description: Timestamp in nanoseconds for when the message sender created the offer.
fields.label: Timestamp
fields.name: Timestamp

fields.description: Serialized Bitcoin transaction. The transaction needs data added by another party upon acceptance of offer.
fields.label: Payload
fields.name: Payload

messages.label: Offer
messages.name: Offer

messages.description: Partially-signed transactions (Tokenized actions, Bitcoin, Multisig, Threshold Signatures, etc.) can be passed around on-chain to the parties (including Smart Contracts) that still have to sign the transaction.

fields.description: Timestamp in nanoseconds for when the message sender creates the transaction.
fields.label: Timestamp
fields.name: Timestamp

fields.description: Full serialized bitcoin tx with multiple inputs from different wallets/users.
fields.label: Payload
fields.name: Payload

messages.label: Signature Request
messages.name: SignatureRequest

messages.description: A message that contains a multi-contract settlement that needs settlement data added by another contract. Sent to another contract to request data be added.

fields.description: Timestamp in nanoseconds for when the message sender creates the transaction.
fields.label: Timestamp
fields.name: Timestamp

fields.description: Tx Id of the transfer request transaction that triggered this message.
fields.label: Transfer Tx Id
fields.name: TransferTxId

fields.description: Contract fees (in bitcoin) and addresses(PKHs) where fees should be paid. Added by each contract as settlement data is added.
fields.label: Contract Fees
fields.name: ContractFees

fields.description: Serialized settlement OP_RETURN that needs data added by another contract.
fields.label: Settlement
fields.name: Settlement

messages.label: Settlement Request
messages.name: SettlementRequest

messages.description: Metadata associated with the output. Aka Transaction details. It is used to describe the purpose of the transaction and add other relevant information. Often encrypted (DH, RSA) to make it private for one or more parties.  DH for b2b where multiple parties can see the description.  RSA or the like for descriptions only visible to one of the transacting parties. Optional

fields.description: A Description that accompanies the output. A transaction description.
fields.example: eg. Invoice 3024, Pay Mike back for camping.
fields.label: Output Description
fields.name: OutputDescription

fields.description: Predefined values for describing the output.
fields.label: Tags
fields.name: Tags

fields.description: Free form text fields for describing the output. Groceries, Moomba Gas Compressor Project, Cash Register 3, Fitness, Entertainment, Special, VIP Section, North Carolina Store, Waitress: Cindy Smith, etc.
fields.label: Custom Tags
fields.name: CustomTags

messages.label: Output Metadata
messages.name: OutputMetadata

messages.description: An administrator is making a distribution/payout. Used to publicly declare these payments and allow holders to be notified of them via the smart contract agent.

fields.description: A unique code that is used to identify the instrument. It is generated by hashing the contract public key hash and the instrument index. SHA256(contract PKH + instrument index)
fields.label: Instrument Code
fields.name: InstrumentCode
fields.notes: Cannot be changed by the administration, operator or smart contract.

fields.description: Timestamp in nanoseconds of when the administrator initiated the distribution.
fields.label: Timestamp
fields.name: Timestamp

messages.label: Distribution

outputs.label: Contract Public Address for Instrument X
outputs.name: InstrumentContract

messages.name: Distribution

messages.description: A message used to initiate a new relationship between 2 or more parties. The M1 container specifies the sender tx input and requested participant tx outputs. If there are more than 2 parties the encryption secret provided in the envelope protocol is used as the base encryption secret. If there are only 2 parties, then the ECDH secret of each key pair is used to encrypt each message.

fields.description: The type or purposed of the relationship. 0 - Conversation (direct messages), 1 - Channel (entity/business to entity/business)
fields.label: Type
fields.name: Type

fields.description: The seed used to derive keys for the relationship.
fields.label: Seed
fields.name: Seed

fields.description: The flag can optionally be used to identify messages in the relationship so that all members don't have to be tagged in each message. It isn't needed for two party relationships, but is recommended for relationships with more members. It will be included in it's own op return for all message transactions. It is recommended to be a random 20 byte value similar to public key hashes. The flag will be the Payload of an Envelope protocol message with a Payload Protocol ID of "F". If this value is not specified then there must be an output to the next key in the relationship chain for every member in the group.
fields.label: Flag
fields.name: Flag

fields.description: Type of encryption used for messages within the relationship. 0 - Encryption keys embedded in envelope protocol. 1 - Encryption key embedded in this message is used as base key for future messages. Used for relationships with more than 2 members so the encryption key doesn't have to be encrypted to each member in every message.
fields.label: Encryption Type
fields.name: EncryptionType

fields.description: The type/format of the sender's proof of identity.
fields.label: Proof of Identity Type
fields.name: ProofOfIdentityType

fields.description: Sender's proof of identity.
fields.label: Proof of Identity
fields.name: ProofOfIdentity

fields.description: Information about the entities in the channel. Not included if this is not a channel initiation. These represent the companies in a channel. A channel is recommended to have 2 entities and several individual members per party. The individual members can discuss terms while the parties are used for official actions.
fields.label: Channel Parties
fields.name: ChannelParties

messages.label: Initiate Relationship
messages.name: InitiateRelationship

messages.description: A pending accept to a relationship that provides information about a requested participant.

fields.description: The type/format of the sender's proof of identity.
fields.label: Proof of Identity Type

fields.description: Sender's proof of identity.
fields.label: Proof of Identity

messages.description: Amend a relationship. Add/Remove members. Modify permissions. This is encrypted with the current base encryption secret, but can provide a new base encryption secret that starts after this message.

fields.description: The new seed used to derive keys for the relationship after this message.
fields.label: Seed
fields.name: Seed

fields.description: The new base encryption secret used to derive encryption secrets for the relationship after this message. Each time a message is sent, the current seed hash is added to the base encryption secret and that value is used to encrypt the message.
fields.label: Base Encryption Secret
fields.name: BaseEncryptionSecret

fields.description: Indexes to the outputs of the members that are being added to the group.
fields.label: Add Member Indexes
fields.name: AddMemberIndexes

fields.description: Indexes to the outputs of the members that are being removed from the group.
fields.label: Drop Member Indexes
fields.name: DropMemberIndexes

messages.label: Relationship Amendment
messages.name: RelationshipAmendment

messages.description: Start a thread from within a conversation or channel.

fields.description: The flag is required to identify messages in the thread so that all members don't have to be tagged in each message. It is recommended to be a random 20 byte value similar to public key hashes. The flag will be the Payload of an Envelope protocol message with a Payload Protocol ID of "F"
fields.label: Flag
fields.name: Flag

fields.description: The seed used to derive keys for the thread. If this value is not specified, then the original seed value from the parent conversation or channel is used.
fields.label: Seed
fields.name: Seed

messages.label: Initiate Thread
messages.name: InitiateThread

resources.description: Roles that entities play in relation to their interactions with other entities. These roles have widely-accepted tasks, rights and duties.
resources.name: Roles

resources.description: Predefined tags for output metadata. Multiple values can be assigned to an output to describe a tx output.
resources.name: Tags
